comments:
This course investigates methods of economic analysis for decision-making
among alternative courses of action in engineering applications. The topics covered
include cost-driven design economics, break-even analysis, money-time relationships,
rates of return, cost estimation, depreciation, taxes, foreign exchange rates, life cycle
analysis, benefit-cost ratios, risk analysis, capital financing and allocation, and financial
statement analysis. Case studies apply these topics to actual engineering problems.
Students for the most part found this “interesting” course to be “worthwhile.”
Students felt that they learned a lot throughout the semester and the knowledge they
gained was very applicable to real world situations.
Students that took this course felt that Professor Cassel was a great professor that
explained concepts well. They also felt that he organized the course very well.
This course required a lot of work and covers a lot of material in a short period of
time. The case studies, in addition the weekly homework assignments, necessitated a
large time commitment. Students felt that Professor Cassel had “no mercy” in the amount
of work that he assigned. The only prerequisite for this course is knowledge of
differential calculus.
